title: The Breakup Was Supposed to Break Me. Instead, It Sent Me to the Dominican Republic
text:
The Breakup Was Supposed to Break Me. Instead, It Sent Me to the Dominican Republic

Itâ€™s a Sunday afternoon. Iâ€™m sitting in a quiet Queens cafe, stirring my coffee across from the man I love when he says, calmly and rehearsed, â€œIâ€™ve never truly loved you. And I donâ€™t think I ever will.â€

Ouch. Safe to say, blueberry pancakes will never taste the same again.Â 

What followed was every stage of heartbreak you can imagine. Remorse, regret, rumination. I was moving through the world carrying the weight of loving someone who, if Iâ€™m being honest, didnâ€™t even like me most days. Crying on the subway became a routine and Olivia Deanâ€™s The Art of Loving became my lifeline.Â 

Just when I thought the world had shrunk to the size of my grief, life threw me a bone â€” a random, unexpected invitation to Club Med in the Dominican Republic. I didnâ€™t know it yet, but this was the plot twist my heart so desperately needed.

A few days later, I was on a plane to the DR with five nights ahead at the all-inclusive Club Med Punta Cana and Club Med MichÃ¨s. Iâ€™d never been to the Dominican, but after hours of Googling, I was convinced Iâ€™d found the perfect escape. After all, nothing heals a heartbreak faster than an open bar, right?

Not quite.

To no oneâ€™s surprise, I spent the first few nights at the resort broken. As Black women, we donâ€™t always feel held in our relationships. The breakup felt like a generational curse. Most days, I felt like I was screaming into the void to be truly seen, accepting half-hearted apologies, and enduring comments meant to make me feel small. Somebody call Madea and tell her to get the grits ready!

Then it clicked. Black women deserve luxury. We deserve softness. And dammit, we deserve an all-inclusive resort! So, I would become my ancestorsâ€™ wildest dreams. I was going to have a love story worth writing, even if the prince charming was me.Â 

So the next day, I dragged myself out of bed, threw on my swimsuit, and decided I was going to become the best boyfriend I ever had.

Spa Time: Luxury Lifts The Soul

My first few days were spent at Club Med Spa: Punta Cana, where I discovered just how much luxury can lift the soul. Mornings started with an Aperol Spritz overlooking the Atlantic from the Buena Vista Lounge. The sun wrapped around me, giving me the warmth Iâ€™d been craving for weeks. The lounge also offered a buffet selection from every corner of the globe, Italian, Asian, Mediterranean, you name it. And did I mention Iâ€™m an emotional eater? I shut that buffet down.

Every evening, I attended one of Club Medâ€™s classic parties. Their iconic all-white party gave me the perfect excuse to put on heels and feel like myself again. Live bands and circus shows pulled me out of my head and I ended up meeting women who spanned across multiple generations each sharing their own chaotic stories about men. And suddenly, I didnâ€™t feel so alone.Â 

Self-care As The Ultimate Breakup Cure

Of course, the self-care didnâ€™t stop there. I dove into Club Medâ€™s Wellness Fusion program, attending yoga classes and guided meditation led by resident experts. I realized reclaiming my peace of mind wasnâ€™t just about escaping heartbreak. It was about actively choosing to nurture myself in every way possible.

The last couple of days were spent at Club Med MichÃ¨s, and let me tell you, this resort was a dream. The two resorts arenâ€™t close to each other, MichÃ¨s is about a two-hour drive east, tucked away in the El Seibo province, surrounded by lush palm groves, rugged mountains, and secluded beaches. The property stretches across 93 acres, offering everything from treetop yoga to Zen pools, making it feel like its own private world.

The buffet at MichÃ¨s felt gourmet and fresh and I happily sampled everything, for research purposes, of course.Â 

Dancing It Out & Letting The Sun Set On Heartbreak

And then there was Michesâ€™ all-white party. I drank with new friends from all over the globe, screamed Justin Bieberâ€™s â€œBabyâ€ at the top of my lungs. It was a moment of pure, chaotic joy and a reminder of how big the world really is.

And last but not least, the beach. This was my favorite part. The sun danced across the turquoise waves and to no oneâ€™s surprise, I cried. Not from sadness, but appreciation for being alive. To be able to love and to feel. Honestly, I could have stayed there forever.Â 

With sunsets on horseback, spa treatments, and yoga flows as part of Club Medâ€™s Wellness Fusion program, I realized MichÃ¨s wasnâ€™t just a vacation, it was a masterclass in reclaiming peace, indulgence, and joy.

Listen, men suck. And they have since the beginning of time. The trip didnâ€™t completely erase my heartbreak, but it reminded me thereâ€™s so much more to life than one personâ€™s opinion. Thereâ€™s joy, connection, and peace waiting to be found. You donâ€™t need an all-inclusive resort to heal, but sometimes it helps to step away, tend to your spirit, and let the world slow down. As I continue this journey of self-discovery, I hope to carry this sense of wonder and ease wherever I go.

title: Bel-Air Is Ending, But The Cast Says The Showâ€™s Legacy Will Live On
text:
Bel-Air Is Ending, But The Cast Says The Showâ€™s Legacy Will Live On

As a major fan of the original The Fresh Prince of Bel Air, I was hesitant but eager to see what its reboot Bel Air would bring to the characters I hold very dear to my heart. In 2022 when the show premiered, I loved it instantly. Recently, weâ€™ve seen so many reboots come and go, but Peacockâ€™s Bel Air has succeeded where others have failed . By taking a beloved 30-minute sitcom and turning it into a compelling & layered one-hour drama, Bel-Air brought something fresh and exciting to the Fresh Prince franchise. The storylines and character arcs were so detailed and nuanced that it felt similar but brand new. While the show is indeed a drama that gets the heart pumping â€” looking at you, Geoffrey â€” it still has the warm feeling of a family truly showing what it means to show up for one another. For three seasons, Iâ€™ve laughed and even cried while watching Bel Air, and trust me, Season 4 will continue to take us on a rollercoaster of emotions. I was heartbroken when it was announced that this would be Bel-Airâ€™s last season,Â 

What started as a concept on YouTube six years ago by Morgan Cooper has since flourished into Peacockâ€™s longest running and most streamed original series. The execution of this show from start to finish is a testament to Black ingenuity and a reminder that art is for all of us. As Cassandra Freeman, who plays Aunt Viv told me over Zoom, â€œYour vision is not trite, it is worthy.â€ She continued: â€œThe greatest artistic expression is [that] you were born to change other peopleâ€™s lives with your vision..â€ A word.

Ahead of the Season 4 premiere, I was able to share some laughs and get insight from Bel-Airâ€™s cast on how they feel about the seriesâ€™ final season, the growth ofÂ  their characters,Â  and the legacy they think Bel Air will leave.

Refinery29: Congrats on the final season! â€ŠHow do you feel about the growth of your characters over four seasons?

Coco Jones (Hilary Banks): I feel pretty satisfied with my growth. I think that Hilary started off [more] surface.Â  Sheâ€™s this influencer, this cute girl with sickening outfits. It was very lighthearted at the beginning and then you get to unravel the plights that she goes through and itâ€™s real life. [Now, sheâ€™s] feeling like she doesnâ€™t have a seat at the table and wanting to be the chef and people wanting to downplay her recipes, like theyâ€™re too spicy. This girl comes from this zip code, this net worth, but it didnâ€™t buy her this easy life. It doesnâ€™t buy her self-discovery. She still has to go through the highs and lows to figure out who she is. Iâ€™ve enjoyed really playing her, her arcs and her peaks and valleys.

Akira Akbar (Ashley Banks): I feel really satisfied with Ashleyâ€™s growth among these seasons. We really got to see a teenage girl and what she goes through. When I was a younger teenager, I fully didnâ€™t know who I was. I was still trying to figure out myself. I was exactly like Ashley. I think the writers really did a great job of portraying that on screen.

Cassandra Freeman (Aunt Viv): [Viv] started off as a politicianâ€™s wife, and by the end of this, she becomes a self-expressed artist. Itâ€™s been an amazing journey to play her. Sheâ€™s trying to figure out how to speak her truth and take care of other people and [she] realizes the best way to take care of other people is to take care of yourself first. Take care of your passions first. Tell people the truth first. Itâ€™s been an honor to play her storyline.

Olly Sholotan (Carlton Banks): Iâ€™ve never been happier. I think that the beautiful thing that these writers have done is theyâ€™ve taken such good care of our charactersâ€™ journeys, and I just know that by the time you get to the very end, fans are gonna be so proud of Carltonâ€™s growth.

Jabari Banks (Will Smith): I was gonna say proud. Proud of the people that our characters have become. Proud of their journeys and proud of where theyâ€™re going next.Â 

Jimmy Akingbola (Geoffrey Thompson):â€Š We started very gentle with Geoffrey. It was a lot of sitting in a mystery and not resting on the wave of nostalgia. Iâ€™m an actor that loves to get my hands dirty. [Iâ€™ll roll] up my sleeves, gimme the ball, let me play. So I was very happy when we got into Season 3, where we got to see behind the layers of Geoffrey. I think Season 4 is the perfect way to sort of wrap things up because again, his past comes through the door. My key word for this season for Geoffrey is fracture. He fractures everything that he built with the Banks family. And I think it teaches you that there are consequences to every action you do in life. And this is the first time that Geoffrey is not in controlâ€¦ Heâ€™s under pressure.Â 

Jordan L. Jones (Jazz): Just the growth of my character in general has just been a blessing because when we first get the roles, itâ€™s like youâ€™re just cool with whatever. Iâ€™m playing Jazz. Iâ€™m not a part of the family, but my character has layers and layers and layers and layers. Coming up to Season 4, I think one of the main themes is about Jazzâ€™s evolution [and] unconditional love. And just being strong enough to tell your significant other, or the person that you love, how you actually feel no matter what the circumstances are. As men too, we need to do that more often instead of trying to be hard all the time. Thatâ€™s one thing that my character definitely has taught me. Some of the things that sound weak or feel weak or seem like what you shouldnâ€™t do, [arenâ€™t like that at all]. It feels like donâ€™t express your feelings this way, but no, actually, instead of thinking thatâ€™s weak, I think that it actually takes a very strong person to do that.

Adrian Holmes [Uncle Phil]: Philip Banks started out being that pillar for the family and over time, we start to see cracks in that pillar and just howÂ  life has weighed on him and the pressures of being perfect. I think that the theme for him is legacy and building legacy is not what we leave behind for the next generation. Itâ€™s what we leave within the next generation â€” the impact, the lives we change, you know. I think that Philip has done a great job over the arc of this series in just empowering Will, empowering Carlton, and the family, and just letting them know that they are enough and they have all the tools they need and just really building them up to be the best versions of themselves. Also just embracing the simple things in life and inner peace. I think heâ€™s just been so busy outside, looking outside that he hasnâ€™t been able to really focus on the inside and over the time where we see him in this season, he starts to really look within more and appreciate the little things.

What mark or message do you think Bel Air will leave once it is over?

Coco: If I had to say it would be to stay close to the people who love you back. You know, at the end of the day, they will be your support system. And you can have great accomplishments, but donâ€™t forget the people who love you back and who really, truly know you because thereâ€™s always seasons and things change. And you wanna have the people that will always support you as close to you as possible.

Cassandra: â€ŠTitles change, positions fade, great successes get forgotten. But family is why they say charity starts at home.Thatâ€™s the first one. And then the second thing is outside of the show, just the birth of it. I hope people realize if you have a great idea, you too can be Morgan Cooper and drop your thesis for an idea on YouTube. And your platform is how many people agree with you. And you not only will change your life, youâ€™ll change everyone elseâ€™s life. Thatâ€™s the greatest artistic expression. You were born to change other peopleâ€™s lives with your vision. Your vision is not trite, it is worthy.Â 

â€‹â€‹Akira: I think the biggest takeaway from Bel Air is family over everything. You can have all the friends in the world. They can come and go, but your family is always there

Simone Jones: I feel like itâ€™s the ability to reinvent yourself and love yourself while you do it. And, also to really take care of your community because weâ€™re gonna mess up. I feel like relationships now have become very temporary and very fragile. And so to watch,even just as a cast, we go through like our teens together in LA and something youâ€™ve never seen before, and watching these characters kind of mirror a similar turbulent time. I think I want people to leave with, like, your community is really important to yourself and also everybody else.

Olly: Man, Simone really took the words just kind of right outta my mouth. So everything she said, but put it in a slightly deeper voice.

Jabari: She said something thatÂ  really stuck me there too. The reinvention, uh, you know, reinvention and, not being afraid to reinvent yourself. Not being afraid to reinvent in general. You know weâ€™ve shown the world that just â€™cause you know, you reinvent something doesnâ€™t mean that it has to be corny or it doesnâ€™t mean that it has to, you know what Iâ€™m saying? It can be a totally different thing, you know?Â  We are the living proof of that.Â 

Jordan: â€ŠI think for me, I think for our theme has been constant throughout four seasons, where like weâ€™re just showing, all aspects of the Black experience. What I love about our show is that each one of our characters is going through a different black experience. We got me like the hustler. Thatâ€™s like, Iâ€™m not broke, but I ainâ€™t, I ainâ€™t Uncle Phil, you know? Uncle Philâ€™s like the leader of the household. And then we, then we got Geoffery, whoâ€™s black 007. We got Will fish outta water. We got Carlton, who is very privileged. So itâ€™s like I can, I can go down the line, but weâ€™re showing that the black experience,Â 

Adrian: Weâ€™re not a monolith.

Jordan: The black experience is not just one experience, like, come over here weâ€™re black this is what we do. Itâ€™s not like that, you know?Â 

Adrian: Absolutely. Weâ€™re not defined by our trauma or our struggle. â€ŠYou know, our joy is something to be celebrated. Our joy is our superpower. Itâ€™s our fuel, and thatâ€™s what keeps us resilient. I always say, we can bend, but donâ€™t break. Our black joy is what prevents us from, from breaking and always surviving no matter how difficult the situations are. The issue is we always find a way to prevail. Our show, Bel Air has done a fantastic job of really showcasing that, you know?. Weâ€™re not a monolith. We are redefining what the black experience looks like on television.We need more of that narrative moving forward. â€ŠAnd hopefully thereâ€™s not a huge void after our show.Â 

All right, weâ€™re going to end on a game called Bothered or Unbothered. Iâ€™m gonna throw you some rapid-fires questions and your answer is either Bothered or Unbothered.Â 

Keeping family secrets. Bothered or Unbothered?

Coco: Hmm. Bothered. I [like to] get everything out in the open. I really love therapy and I canâ€™t with a secret. Itâ€™s like mold. Itâ€™s just going to get everywhere.Â  Plus, I canâ€™t remember everything I done said. Now I gotta keep up with the lies. I donâ€™t know what I just said to you.

Cassandra: Iâ€™m kind of unbothered because Iâ€™m starting to realize that if I am interested in what youâ€™re cooking up all the time and in your pot, it just steals my joy. You can live your whole life knowing everybodyâ€™s secrets and never even deal with your own. So if itâ€™s my secrets, Iâ€™m bothered. Iâ€™m gonna get it out. If it ainâ€™t bothering me in my house, listen, you go over there. I ainâ€™t got time for that. Itâ€™s too much, Iâ€™m unbothered.Â Â 

Akira: My secret, I feel like Iâ€™ll be bothered and Iâ€™ll be like, I need to tell somebody, but someone elseâ€™s I donâ€™t care.

Jordan: Unbothered by that.

Jimmy: Unbothered!

Adrian: Unbothered.

Jordan: Everybody donâ€™t have to know what your family is going through.

Jabari: It depends on the secret.

Olly: Yeah. Like keeping family [secrets] in the family? Bothered. But Iâ€™m OK with keeping family secrets from outside people. I ainâ€™t trying to tell our business.Â 

Jabari: Sometimes you gotta keep a little secret. Sometimes you have to. Itâ€™s best for the family. Mom donâ€™t need to know that. Mom donâ€™t need to know what Cuzzo did when we went out. Mom donâ€™t need to know that. Keep it secret.

Olly: I think whatâ€™s in the dark will always come to the light, so I donâ€™t know about this one.

Simone: Oh no. I feel Iâ€™m a big fan of everybody having all the information and then doing what you will with it.
